sentence.text: A 44-year-old woman who was seeking genetic counseling was referred to the clinic for evaluation of dysmorphic features and short stature.
She had been born after an uneventful pregnancy as the third child of first cousin-related parents of Turkish descent.
The remainder of the family history was non-contributory.
She had good verbal communication skills along with normal motor developmental milestones.
A formal psychometric evaluation was not made.
Unfortunately, due to social reasons, her schooling was interrupted at the elementary level.
Audiological assessment revealed bilateral, moderate degree, mixed type hearing loss.
She had undergone one reconstructive facial operation and a series of further operations were planned.
On examination, the patient had short-limb short stature, with height of 118 cm (<3rd centile).
Head circumference was 55.5 cm (0.5 SD) and weight was 17 kg (<3rd centile).

There was frontal bossing, temporal baldness, vertical skin creases of forehead, high arched eyebrows, narrow palpebral fissures with deep set globes, hypertelorism, low-set ears with posterior rotation and dysplasia of conchae, ear lobe and antitragus, preauricular skin tags, narrow auditory canals, a short neck, redundant skin folds at the back, and a low posterior hairline (Fig. 1).
She also had extreme limitation of movement of both upper and lower extremities including fixed flexion at the elbow joints and bilateral dislocation of the hips with fixed flexion.
The main radiographic features were hypoplastic scapulae and iliac bones, short humerus and femurs, humeroradial synostosis, and mild brachydactyly (Fig. 2B,C).
The neurocranium appeared small, there was thickening of the cranial vault, and the facial bones were more prominent compared to the neurocranium (Fig. 2A).
Cranial computerized tomography demonstrated increased pericerebral spaces, interpreted as mild atrophy of brain and cerebellum.
Abdominal ultrasonography revealed a hemorrhagic ovarian cyst and arcuate uterus.
Endocrine work-up including serum FSH, LH, 17-OH progesterone, cortisone, DHEA sulphate, testosterone and free testosterone levels were all within normal values.
Renal function tests, urine analysis, and HbA1C levels were also normal.
On the basis of characteristic clinical and radiographic features, a diagnosis of Cousin syndrome was suspected.
With informed consent of the patient, molecular investigations were started
